Title: Proof that rational functions are an ordered field, but non-archimedean - Bartle's elements of real analysis
Content: I read that the set of rational functions with rational coefficients forms an ordered field, yet it is non-archimedean. I tried googling this, but I don't think I understood the solution. How does one define an order on rational functions of the form $\mathbb{Q}(x)=p(x)/q(x)$ ? How do you show that $\mathbb{Q}(x)$ is non-archimedean? That there is no natural number $n$ , such that $n>\mathbb{Q}(x)$ ? Do I substitute numerical values of $x$ and show that $\mathbb{Q}(x)$ is unbounded or something?
AcceptedAnswer:
Consider the following order: let $f(x)=p(x)/q(x)$ be a rational function with \begin{aligned}p(x)=a\cdot x^n &+ \text{ terms of degree less than $n$}\\
q(x)=b\cdot x^m &+ \text{ terms of degree less than $m$}\end{aligned} where of course $a,b \in \mathbb{Q}$. Our order says that $f > 0$ if and only if $\frac{a}{b} >0$. Notice this defines the order throughout the field; if one wishes to determine whether $f_1 > f_2$, write the difference $f_1-f_2$ as a single rational function and determine whether it is $>0$, $=0$ or $<0$. Now, this totally ordered field is not Archimedean. Indeed, consider the rational functions $f(x)=x$ and $g(x) = 1$. No matter how large you choose $n \in \mathbb{N}$, $f(x)>n\cdot g(x)$, because $\big(f-n\cdot g\big)(x)=x-n$ and the leading coefficient of $\big(f-n\cdot g\big)$ is $1$, which is positive.

3. If f ≤ g, then f + h ≤ g + h (translation invariance).
4. If f ≥ 0 and g ≥ 0, then fg ≥ 0 (closure under multiplication).

Now, how do we define such an order on rational functions? The key idea I remember is to use the concept of "behavior at infinity." For rational functions, we can compare them based on their leading terms as x approaches infinity. For example, if we have two polynomials p(x) and q(x), the rational function p(x)/q(x) will dominate based on the degrees of the numerator and denominator. If the degree of p is higher than q, the function tends to infinity as x grows; if the degrees are equal, we compare the leading coefficients; if the degree of p is lower, it tends to zero. This seems like a way to define an order.

So, to define the order formally, for a rational function f(x) = p(x)/q(x) where p and q are polynomials with coefficients in ℚ and q ≠ 0, we can look at the leading coefficients and degrees. Let’s denote the leading term of p(x) as a_n x^n and of q(x) as b_m x^m. Then, the leading term of f(x) is (a_n / b_m) x^{n - m}. 

The order can then be defined as follows: f > 0 if and only if the leading coefficient a_n / b_m is positive. Then, for two rational functions f and g, we say f > g if f - g > 0. This should satisfy the properties of an ordered field.
